subject: Philosophy
title: The Ship of Theseus
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Ship of Theseus.

hook.text: If you replace every plank of a ship, one by one, is it still the same ship?

buildup.text: The ancient Greeks debated this. It challenges what we mean by identity over time.

discovery.text: Your body replaces most of its cells every seven to ten years. Are you the same person you were at age five?

twist.text: What if someone rebuilt the original ship from the old planks? Now there are two ships. Which one is 'the' ship?

climax.text: Identity might not be a fact. It might be a story we tell ‚Äî useful but ultimately fuzzy.

punchline.text: Same name, new parts. Identity is a narrative.

quiz.question: What does the Ship of Theseus problem question?
options: Whether identity persists when all parts are replaced
